text: YouTube lists of best films are usually difficult to read. Anglo-American lists are, for the most part insufferable privileging every manner of mediocre but culturally significant American film. But this list is different. Of course it's not the list I would make; lists are too subjective for that to be possible. But this list has three admirable qualities: it's self-reflective, it's cinematically cosmopolitan & historicist, and it views cinematic art as something beyond story-telling. Besides, it is so rare for lists like these to actually have all-time great works like Bela Tarr's Satantango, reason enough for me to like this list!

text:
A few observations now having finished the list.

There's a podcast that goes minute by minute through the Lord of The Rings extended cut. Each episode is at least 20 minutes, some a lot longer. The films do have their small flaws but yeah, the logistical effort and how much that pays off on screen - its the peak of that type of Cinema.

I prefer A Clockwork Orange but I accept that 2001 is the better film, technically.

The Godfather is great, but again not just to be a contrarian, I like The Conversation more. If I was going to have a Gangster film on my list, Miller's Crossing is my favourite for personal reasons (I have a whole head-canon that I desperately need to ask Gabriel Byrne about should I ever meet him) and I prefer Goodfellas, it doesn't mystify the whole organised crime thing.

Spirited Away is awesome but its not even the best film by that director an only arguably just makes the top 5 of the studio. Totoro, Kaguya, Mononoke, Fireflies and maybe then Spirited away but Whisper Of The Heart, The Red Turtle, Kiki's could go ahead of it and at least one of those would for me. 

I feel like Satoshi Kon should make an appearance on anyone's top-list, even just on the basis of the editing. He did 4 basically perfect films with great art-direction, good stories, memorable characters and he put them together with masterful editing and lots of subtle visual motifs and details.

Gone With The Wind is one that I'd never have on a top list even if I actually liked it that much (haven't seen the whole thing since I was a teenager, recall it being bloated and melodramatic) for the same reason I wouldn't have any Roman Polanski films on mine, the context is sufficient that it trumps whatever objective qualities the work has. It is white nationalist agit-prop, no less than anything by Leni Riefenstahl, more dangerous even because its not seen that way by most casual viewers. Its politics were rotten at the time, and have only got worse in retrospect.

text:
I think the following films can be honorable mentioned.

Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs (1937) from Disney during the early days of sound and color, the animated masterpiece was a landmark in the animation and filming process. It was not only an achievement in production and technical prowess, but it was also the first of Disney‚Äôs version of iconic fairytales retold through his lens. For almost a hundred years, we are still influenced by Disney's spells.

The Apu Trilogy: Pather Panchali (1955), Aparajito (1956), and Apur Sansar (1959) from Satyajit Ray followed the life of Apu from a poor childhood to a college-educated alum and reluctantly married and falls in love with a disgraced bride to be only to abandon the child they have after her death. It‚Äôs a coming-of-age story told beautifully and intimately through three sprawling films, which Marvel Cinematic Universe tried to replicate with their Tom Holland‚Äôs Spider-Man three-film arc about a boy growing up to be a man and taking responsibility for his actions.

Everything Everywhere All At Once (2022). Wait, this is a brand new film, just a baby born this year! Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert have weaved an intricate tale about generational family trauma, immigration experience, and nihilism. It‚Äôs got drama, action, family, and interdimensional interference. Most importantly, it has a heart. In all the craziness and overblown gags and atrocities, the message is to be kind, then nothing matters, and we learn to do laundry and taxes. I am making a bold prediction, Everything Everywhere All At Once will be picked by The Library of Congress for being "culturally, historically, or aesthetically significant."

text: Citizen Kane only changed the perception of cinema as high art in Hollywood/USA. In Europe, the avant-garde filmmakers from German Expressionism, French Impressionism, Soviet montage theory, Surrealism, Poetic Realism and the very beginnings/antecedents of Italian Neorealism had already changed the face of cinema much earlier. I'm not downplaying Citizen Kane's importance - it remains one of the most influential films ever made, especially for its formalism while Hollywood was still finding its own language. However, it seems presumptuous to think that this film alone and not the European movements before it changed the face of cinema.

author: Jimmy1982*Playlists

text:
The narrative, non-linear structure of KANE is part of what makes it special. We take that for granted now, but films of that grand scale and sweep hadn‚Äôt done that before. Also, use of sound: all the art movements the OP listed don‚Äôt employ sound the same. 60% of a movie is its sound, and European films, at that time rarely, rivaled a Hollywood film in the audio department. ‚ÄúChanging the face of cinema‚Äù isn‚Äôt just the visuals, unacceptable sound will turn away viewers much faster than unacceptable images. KANE pushed deep-focus photography to new heights as well as use of dozens of VFX shots pioneered by others yet deployed in a single film ‚Äî again, a first, that is also taken for granted 80 years later. As with many works of art, no one is working in a vacuum, borrowing and remixing is part of it. That‚Äôs also something KANE did head and shoulders above vast majority of European films pre1941. Also, with Welles being so young, the film probably inspired far more filmmakers to attempt to make films before 25 with such lasting gravitas. 99% fail at that; that level of impact is also rarely recognized. Yet, how important is that for the art form? 

The shadow this single film casts is, perhaps unprecedented and unable to be duplicated. A single film not an art movement (all of which I adore, btw). All this to say, KANE might not be number 1 but it should be in the running of top 3 or 5 always. 

There‚Äôs an excellent doc here on YouYube called Cinema Europa from late ‚Äò90s, it delves into the various luminaries of European national cinemas, and you see some fantastic work from those art movements, so I‚Äôm not downplaying their greatness. However, KANE does so many thing already in the ideaspace at the top of the game AND had a bold storytelling modality. It‚Äôs not always about doing it first, context and impact must be considered too.

text:
¬†@drumbum3.14¬† Stories don't need to talk about things like morality, humanity, or things like strength or whatever. A story should be good, and The Godfather Parts 1 and 2 are about as good as it gets. Some of their primary ideas are related to the nature of evil in every person's soul, the importance of family, how power corrupts, and the idea of a man losing his soul to his business. 

The reason they're superior is simply because they're better crafted. From a technical side, it's among the best with masterful direction, sound design/editing, and near-unrivaled lighting. It's one of the most perfectly paced stories ever told, and there isn't a single frame that's out of place. And, as many have said before, it delivers one of the strongest character arcs ever put on the screen.
